title: 103_hr4308
content: The Act titled "North American Wetlands Conservation Act Amendments of 1994" includes requirements for matching, reporting, and revising. The North American Wetlands Conservation Act Amendments of 1994 include provisions for matching requirements, reporting to Congress, and revisions to the conservation plan. The amendments allow for cash contributions from non-United States sources for projects in Mexico, require reporting on wetlands conservation projects funded under the Act, and outline revisions to the conservation plan. Revisions to the North American Wetlands Conservation Act include changing the year from 1991 to 1998, adding Mexico to the plan along with Canada, and removing the second sentence. The North American Wetlands Conservation Act is amended to include a new section for assessing progress in wetlands conservation. The Secretary and the Council will develop a strategy to conserve North American wetlands systems and species, and monitor the effectiveness of conservation projects under the Act. Authorization of appropriations for allocations under the North American Wetlands Conservation Act is also amended. The North American Wetlands Conservation Act is amended to increase funding to $20,000,000 for fiscal years 1995 and 1996, and $30,000,000 for fiscal years 1997 and 1998. SEC. 5 amends the Coastal Wetlands Planning, Protection and Restoration Act to focus on conservation in coastal wetlands ecosystems. SEC. 6 establishes the Wildlife Partnership Program. The Partnerships For Wildlife Act (16 U.S.C. 3741 et seq.) is amended to define the term 'designated State agency' and make various technical corrections. The Partnerships For Wildlife Act (16 U.S.C. 3741 et seq.) is amended to define the term 'State' as any of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, the United States Virgin Islands, or American Samoa. Amendments are made to section 7105(d) and section 7105 regarding the non-Federal share of projects. Amendments to the Partnerships For Wildlife Act require that at least one-third of the total cost of projects funded by the Secretary must come from State or private sources, with exceptions for projects involving cooperation between designated State agencies. Payments must be monetary and not in-kind contributions. Amendments to the Partnerships For Wildlife Act state that if designated State agencies from 2 or more States cooperate on a project, at least 30 percent of the funding must come from such sources. Contributions can be in the form of private cash donations, materials, equipment, or services. The Secretary can use up to 4 percent of the funds for administering the chapter and evaluating projects. Amendments to the Partnerships For Wildlife Act involve changes to section 7105(h) (16 U.S.C. 3744(h)), including updating the year from 1995 to 1998 and removing the requirement to match contributions made to the Fund by the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation.
